b'Liza Mustapha has been with PETRONAS for two decades, holding positions as Chief Financial Officer at PETRONAS Gas Bhd and at PETRONAS\xe2\x80\x99 Upstream business.

A PETRONAS scholar, she joined PETRONAS as a Finance Executive back in 1995. She has come a long way since she \xc2\xa0enrolled in her \xc2\xa0A-Level studies at Concord College in the UK under the PETRONAS Education Scholarship Programme (PESP). Her journey as a PETRONAS scholar took her to the renowned London School of Economics where she graduated with a Bachelor of Science in Economics.

\xe2\x80\x9cBeing a student away from home at the time, the PETRONAS student officers in London knew us all by name. It was then that I began to wear the PETRONAS badge with pride,\xe2\x80\x9d said Liza.

The journey of talent development with PETRONAS has now led Liza to the senior leadership table.

She is now the Senior Vice President and Group Chief Financial Officer. She has earned her spot in the organisation\xe2\x80\x99s 46-year history as its first woman CFO, a position that many finance professionals can aspire to.

b'While fossil fuels remain core to the global energy mix, PETRONAS is redefining its energy offerings by pushing for the increased use of natural gas, which the company sees as complementary to renewables to support its sustainable agenda.

At the forefront of this, Dr Khalik works tirelessly on new separation technologies for efficient removal of high CO2 content from natural gas streams. Dr Khalik\xe2\x80\x99s groundbreaking research aims at using water as the main solvent in the separation process through formation of gas hydrate, making the process both cheaper and greener.

Born in Kuching, Sarawak, Dr Khalik Mohamad Sabil is currently the Technology Manager for Research & Development Subsurface, Gas Sustainability Technology for PETRONAS.

Dr Khalik made us proud when he became the first scientist in PETRONAS to receive the prestigious title of Honorary Research Fellow by Heriot-Watt University, United Kingdom recently. To date, he has published more than 80 referenced articles with over 1,700 citations. Congratulations, Dr Khalik!

His vast experience and significant reputation from his contributions towards research and development in the industry was key in the selection for these awards which also serves as recognition for PETRONAS\xe2\x80\x99 contribution in the field of energy and sustainability.

Married with two children, Dr Khalik emphasised the importance of striking a balance between family, work and personal well-being. When he takes off the lab coat, Dr Khalik is an endurance athlete. This scientist has completed Ironman 70.3, several triathlons and full marathons, saying it taught him the value of patience  and perseverance while recognising his own strengths and weaknesses,  and the importance of setting goals in life.

b'PETRONAS President & Group CEO Tengku Taufik Says Sees Opportunity In New Energy Sources That Will Complement Its Global LNG Portfolio, Including Hydrogen.
 

PETRONAS President & Group CEO Tengku Taufik Friday said that natural gas remains core to PETRONAS as a cleaner source of fossil fuel, offering a suitable solution towards ensuring the energy needs of Southeast Asia\xe2\x80\x99s burgeoning population. However, PETRONAS is also seeing opportunities in new energy sources, apart from solar and wind that will complement its global Liquified Natural Gas (LNG) portfolio, and this includes hydrogen, where the Company is now working towards sustainable coalitions with technology providers to develop zero-emission hydrogen fuel from bio-based products and carbon engineering. He said this at the APEC CEO Dialogues 2020.
 
More recently, PETRONAS announced  its aspiration to achieve Net Zero Carbon Emissions by 2050 as part of its holistic approach to  sustainability that balances Environment, Social and Governance (ESG) considerations which are aligned to its statement of purpose, namely to be a \xe2\x80\x98progressive energy and solutions partner enriching lives for a sustainable future\xe2\x80\x99.
 
At the forum, Tengku Taufik also highlighted technology challenges in addressing carbon emissions, the long-term outlook and impact of investing in North America, and the sensitivities and scenarios around carbon tax pricing.'

b'What does it take for an ordinary guy from Seri Kembangan to be a part of the winning formula for the Mercedes-AMG PETRONAS Formula One Team?

In short, a great deal of passion for solving problems and hard work.

En De Liow, who is a graduate from University of Virginia, with a Bachelor\xe2\x80\x99s degree in Mechanical Engineering, and Coventry University, with a Master\xe2\x80\x99s degree in Automotive Engineering, supports the seven-time world champions as a @PETRONAS Trackside Fluid Engineer.

In 2019, En De Liow was handpicked for the job through the PETRONAS Global Talent Search. His job description entails ensuring that all PETRONAS fluids entering the race car (Primax fuel, Syntium engine oil, and Tutela functional fluids) meet FIA regulations and are operating at the highest standards.

He also analyses the used oil before and after each session to monitor the wear and degradation within the engine and gearbox. All this data is then fed back to the wider PETRONAS\xe2\x80\x99 Fluid Technology Solutions team in Malaysia and Italy, assisting their continuous research and development to keep improving the fluids.

Now based in Turin, Italy, near the Global R&T Centre of PETRONAS Lubricants International, En De Liow\xe2\x80\x99s passion for solving problems, whether they are for the racetrack or elsewhere, is as immense as his passion for cars and motorsports.

\xe2\x80\x9cThere is always room to make processes more efficient, to make our environmental footprint smaller, or to improve the quality of life for others through products and services.\xe2\x80\x9d'

b'PETRONAS President & Group CEO Tengku Taufik calls for stronger regional collaboration to support global energy transition

In a special address at the opening of the virtual ASEAN Energy Business Forum (AEBF) 2020 on 18 Nov 2020, PETRONAS President and Group Chief Executive Officer Tengku Muhammad Taufik called for a stronger collaboration amongst ASEAN governments, energy players as well as the public and private sectors to collectively leverage on each other\xe2\x80\x99s strengths in achieving a sustainable, low carbon future. 

To date, ASEAN member countries have collectively endorsed ambitious targets that seek to improve the rate of energy efficiency improvement, limit emissions from fossil fuels and expand the role of renewables especially in the power sector \xe2\x80\x93 positive signs that the region is moving in the right direction.

\xe2\x80\x9cWhile the region has made a start towards carbon neutral energy pathways, there remain further opportunities to strengthen regional cooperation and create the right eco-system to promote a wider usage of energy from clean and sustainable sources, particularly solar and wind. The shift towards a low-carbon future will require coordinated and collective action from all stakeholders,\xe2\x80\x9d Tengku Taufik said.

b'The beaches of Terengganu are some of the most beautiful and pristine in the country, but year by year Zulkefli Sarji watched as they were polluted by litterbugs.

The 51-year-old is the Principal of Rotating Equipment at PETRONAS Penapisan Terengganu Sdn Bhd where he works to ensure that the rotating equipment in the plant is at its highest reliability. At the end of the week though, Zulkefli enjoyed nothing more than spending his weekends at the beach with his family.

One weekend though, while strolling and picking their way through discarded plastic bottles and plastic bags on a Kerteh beach, he decided that things needed to change now, and that he would make the change.

The next week, he and his family walked along the beach and started picking up as much trash as they could find, while his wife Normazita Ali recorded their work and shared it on social media. He even used his own four-wheel drive to transport the rubbish they collected.

Now three years later, Zulkefli is the head of Geng Plastik Ija (GPI), a non-profit organisation that picks litter on the various beaches of Terengganu and packs them in bags. The signature green plastic bag is what gives the group their name (Ija meaning green in Terengganu lingo) . About 70% of Zulkefli\xe2\x80\x99s fellow pickers are now comprised of the local community, with the remaining 30% of the group being staff from PETRONAS, where Zulkefli has worked for 27 years.

When asked, he has a simple explanation for what drives him to sustain Geng Plastik Ija.

"We cannot wait for other people to do it for us. We all have a choice; we can either be a part of the problem or a part of the solution\xe2\x80\x9c

Follow Geng Plastik Ija on Facebook to know more about their programmes.

b"Did you know that 1.3 billion tonnes of food waste is produced every year, and in Malaysia alone, there is 15,000 tonnes of food waste each day? In line with PETRONAS' commitment to the Sustainability Development Agenda in safeguarding the environment, Institut Teknologi Petroleum PETRONAS (INSTEP) has taken the initiative to launch INSTEP Composter House which converts food waste into compost using a composting machine.

The official launching of our composter machine on 19 Aug 2020 witnessed INSTEP's commitment towards zero food waste. INSTEP has stepped up to be the first to implement the food composting technology in PETRONAS, and in Terengganu as well.

INSTEP\xe2\x80\x99s food composter has a 100-kg input capacity per day, which means 100kg of food waste will be converted into 20kg of bio compost within 24 hours. Within a week, 30-40kg of bio compost/fertiliser will be produced, which will then be used for
in campus organic & urban farming, general landscape and soil enhancing.

b'At her home in Kerteh, Wan Afiedatul Syamimi is a doting 31-year-old mother of two who enjoys reading fiction in her spare time. 

When she dons her yellow coveralls at the PETRONAS Chemicals Derivatives plant in Kerteh though, she transforms fluidly into her other persona as a Control System Engineer, a role crucial to the operations of the plant.

Her duties at the Maintenance Department include designing and planning strategies for equipment maintenance and reliability to ensure the smooth operation of the plant. She troubleshoots breakdowns, tests, evaluates and rectifies issues with equipment daily.

Working in the field was not foremost on her mind when she began her career. She had initially planned to work and shine in a corporate environment at the PETRONAS Twin Towers. But she accepted the offer for a technical position when the opportunity presented itself, taking it as a challenge.

Of course, working in a plant can be demanding at times. 

\xe2\x80\x9cThe one thing that kept me going was my supportive team and colleagues. They keep me motivated with positive vibes and this helped me grow. Despite the age and gender difference, they never let me become overwhelmed. I was given numerous opportunities to lead big projects. Sometimes things do get tough when I felt like an ant in this giant industry, but the feeling of accomplishment that came with achieving challenging goals really motivates me.\xe2\x80\x9d

She is happy with her choice of career. \xe2\x80\x9cA great career is when you can see the impact, do work that matters, focus on results, and most importantly, have fun\xe2\x80\x9d, said Afiedatul.

#PETRONAS'

b'October 2019 marked a new beginning for Nurhadayah Sahar when she became an oil tanker truck driver or Delivery Service Partner (Rakan Khidmat Penghantaran) for PETRONAS Dagangan Bhd (PDB).

Being a single mother to a 13-year-old boy, she had initially never imagined making a living as an oil tanker truck driver, traditionally regarded as a job for males.

b'In 1974, when we were just a small company with 15 staff and two phone lines, we introduced our first logo. Operating from an office in the Prime Minister\xe2\x80\x99s Department, we commissioned Johan Design Associates to design the now iconic symbol of PETRONAS.

Malaysians first recognised our trademark at petrol stations that became a familiar sight across the country. Since then, our symbol has transcended our borders to over 50 countries that we operate in across the world.

As we grew, this logo marked every progress and achievement that the Company registered. It was the insignia that appeared in the Fortune 500 list where it has stayed for the last 23 years, the only Malaysian company to date to be recognised in the prominent global listing.

The logo was seen by the eyes of the world when we ventured into the realm of Formula 1 in 1995, via our first sponsorship of the Red Bull Sauber PETRONAS F1 Team, and continues to be emblazoned on the cars of the Mercedes-AMG PETRONAS Team today.

In 2013, we presented a refreshed version of our corporate mark - with a renewed look and feel with softer curves added to the iconic oil drop and letter \xe2\x80\x9cP\xe2\x80\x9d to mark PETRONAS\xe2\x80\x99 continuous flow towards progress and sustainability. This was the third-generation variant, carrying with it the markers of past iterations like the familiar emerald green colour which harkens to the seas and lands where energy originates. In 2019, we introduced our current insignia.

With the originating elements refreshed, the logo as a whole reflects the growth of the PETRONAS brand as a progressive energy and solutions partner enriching lives for a sustainable future. #PETRONAS'

b'Following the official naming ceremony of PETRONAS\xe2\x80\x99 second floating LNG vessel, PETRONAS achieved another major milestone as the PFLNG Dua has officially set sail from South Korea in its maiden voyage to the Rotan Gas Field, located offshore Sabah, Malaysia.

The journey will cover 1,840 nautical miles over a course of approximately two-weeks. Once moored at the Rotan Gas Field, the PFLNG Dua will commence its installation, hook-up and commissioning with the Ready-for-Start-Up (RFSU) date earmarked for mid-2020 and Provisional Acceptance (PA) of the PFLNG Dua by end-2020.

When ready, the PFLNG Dua will be operated by a 120-strong crew and is expected to produce one LNG cargo every fortnight. The PFLNG Dua has the capacity to produce 1.5 million tonnes of LNG per annum and will be one of the worlds\xe2\x80\x99 first floating deep-water LNG vessels capable of reaching remote, stranded and marginal gas reserves located up to 1,500 meters underwater.

The PFLNG Dua was constructed by PETRONAS together with its partners, JGC Corporation and Samsung Heavy Industries, and took approximately 16 million project man-hours to complete since the Engineering, Procurement, Construction, Installation & Commissioning (EPCIC) contract was awarded in May 2014 and involved over 2,800 workers during peak construction.

#PFLNGDUA'
